channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Defiant Bashar al-Assad Vows to Retake ‘Every Inch’ of Syria
item.description: Syria’s president offered no hint of compromise in a national speech, dimming hope for peace talks and rejecting the West’s efforts to provide aid.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Q. and A.: Ramadan Is Here. What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
item.media:description: Muslims praying Sunday in Bali, Indonesia, on the eve of Ramadan.
item.description: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Far-Right Party in Austria Challenges Results of Presidential Vote
item.media:description: The chairman of the Freedom Party of Austria, Heinz-Christian Strache, at a news conference in Vienna on Wednesday.
item.description: The Freedom Party is claiming election irregularities after its candidate, Norbert Hofer, narrowly lost a May 22 runoff.
item.dc:creator: KIMBERLY BRADLEY

item.title: Bomb in Istanbul Kills 11 Near Tourist District
item.description: Explosives in a parked car were detonated by remote control as a police shuttle bus passed through the historic Beyazit area during morning rush hour.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Monkey in Kenya Survives After Setting Off Nationwide Blackout
item.media:description: A monkey that climbed onto the roof of the Gitaru Power Station in Kenya fell or jumped onto a transformer, causing a power outage. The monkey survived and was given to Kenya’s wildlife services.
item.description: The primate jumped on a transformer at a hydroelectric power station, starting a chain reaction that knocked out lights and the internet.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Toxic Fish in Vietnam Idle a Local Industry and Challenge the State
item.media:description: Walking among dead fish on a beach in the central province of Quang Binh, Vietnam, in April. Pollution from a nearby steel plant is suspected in the die-off, and protests across the country are testing the government.
item.description: Hundreds of people have been sickened after eating fish near a new steel plant, and escalating protests have grown into a test of government accountability.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: U.S. Accuses Chinese Jet of Flying Too Close to American Plane
item.media:description: Adm. Harry B. Harris Jr., the head of the United States Pacific Command.
item.media:credit: Logan Mock-Bunting for The New York Times
item.description: The episode was the second report of an unsafe intercept recently by a Chinese jet tracking an American spy plane in the waters around China.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Pall Hangs Over Brazil’s Presidential Palace as Dilma Rousseff Prepares for Trial
item.media:description: Dilma Rousseff, Brazil’s first female president, is allowed to stay at the Palácio da Alvorada, the cavernous residence of the country’s leader, while the fight to oust her once and for all grinds on in the Senate.
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.description: Ms. Rousseff, Brazil’s first female president, was supposed to be preparing to greet world leaders, not enduring the humiliation of an impeachment battle that has her hanging by a thread.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Jordan Bars News Media Coverage of Shooting at Intelligence Office
item.media:description: The Jordanian intelligence office near Amman, the capital, that was attacked on Monday. Five people were killed.
item.description: The shooting near Amman raised fears that militants had been able to penetrate one of the region’s most powerful counterterrorism agencies.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Jewish Woman Detained for Taking Torah Scroll to Western Wall in Jerusalem
item.media:description: An Israeli police officer with Lesley Sachs, the executive director of Women of the Wall, who was briefly arrested on Tuesday while carrying a Torah scroll to the Western Wall.
item.description: The woman, Lesley Sachs, the executive director of Women of the Wall, was held for a few hours after she protested restrictions on women at the holy site.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Papua New Guinea Protesters Wounded by Police Gunfire, Lawmaker Says
item.media:description: Students from the University of Papua New Guinea before the police stopped their demonstration in Port Moresby, the capital, on Wednesday.
item.media:credit: Papua New Guinea FM News, via Reuters
item.description: Officials said some demonstrators had been wounded, but none killed. Students have been demanding that Prime Minister Peter O’Neill resign.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Antonio Imbert Barrera, Who Helped Assassinate Dominican Dictator Trujillo, Dies at 95
item.media:description: Maj. Gen. Antonio Imbert Barrera, right, with Capt. Florio Risk, who is holding the gun General Imbert used to shoot the Dominican dictator Rafael L. Trujillo Molina.
item.description: General Imbert, who had been a businessman became a national hero and for a short time, president, after he and a group of plotters disposed of Rafael L. Trujillo Molina.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Keiko Fujimori Narrows Gap With Pedro Kuczynski in Peru Presidential Vote
item.media:description: Pedro Pablo Kuczynski in Lima, Peru, on Tuesday. As of Tuesday, his led his opponent, Keiko Fujimori, by less than one percent.
item.description: Election officials continued to count ballots on Tuesday. The electoral commission said Mr. Kuczynski led Ms. Fujimori by a razor-thin margin.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: U.N. to Investigate Peacekeepers Reported of Killing Women and Children in Africa
item.description: A report by Human Rights Watch provided new evidence that Congolese peacekeeping soldiers killed civilians in the Central African Republic.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations

item.title: Disenchantment with E.U. Grows, Poll Finds
item.description: The Pew survey of respondents in 10 European countries shows increasing unhappiness with the bloc during a period of low growth and a crisis in migration.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Kenya Bans ‘Unlawful’ Demonstrations
item.media:description: Demonstrators and bystanders on a pedestrian overpass in central Nairobi, Kenya, on Monday as protesters passed underneath.
item.description: The somewhat ambiguous decree followed a day of opposition protests in several parts of the country.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Sinosphere: A Harvard Scholar on the Enduring Lessons of Chinese Philosophy
item.media:description: Tourists and students at the Temple of Confucius in Beijing standing before a statue of the ancient philosopher whose teachings continue to shape Chinese society.
item.description: Michael Puett, whose course on Chinese philosophy is one of Harvard University’s most popular offerings, explains why “embracing ourselves for who we are” may not be the path to the good life.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Will Abba Take a Chance on a Reunion? Performance in Sweden Fuels Fans’ Hopes
item.media:description: Abba performed at the United Nations General Assembly in New York in 1979.
item.description: The band members’ appearance together onstage left many followers clinging to what one historian called a 0.1 percent possibility.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: 5 Catalan Cities Step Away From Spain With New Jewish History Network
item.description: The cities in Catalonia have decided to withdraw from a Spanish network of cities with historic Jewish medieval quarters to create their own network.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Prosecutors Paint Picture of Murder and Deception at Chinese Coal Mines
item.media:description: A coal mine near Ordos, in Inner Mongolia, China. Prosecutors have indicted 74 people on charges of faking mine accidents, swindling, homicide, fraud and blackmail.
item.description: Dozens have been accused of involvement in the deaths of 17 people whose bodies were used to fabricate mine accidents and extract compensation.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Lieyu Township Journal: An Island Tethered to Taiwan, but Leaning Toward China
item.media:description: Cold War-era steel barricades on the shores of Taiwan’s Lieyu Island. The Chinese city of Xiamen is just over three miles away.
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.description: The people of Lieyu Township on Lesser Kinmen Island are linked to Taipei but have prospered as trade and tourism with the mainland have blossomed.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: U.S. and Beijing Offer Competing Views on South China Sea
item.description: The diverging positions by American and Chinese officials indicated that annual talks had done little to bridge differences.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Question of Identity: Why Britain Is Edging Toward ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: A “Vote Leave” rally in Manchester, England. Betting markets still suggest that Britain will remain in the European Union, but recent polls have shown a lead for the “leave” camp.
item.description: Sometimes, one issue can have a big influence on an election. Immigration may turn out to be that issue on June 23.
item.dc:creator: PETER EAVIS

item.title: Sinosphere: China Threatens Jail Time for College Entrance Exam Cheaters
item.media:description: A student emerging from a university entrance exam in Beijing on Tuesday, one of the more than nine million test-takers across China.
item.description: Officials made clear that they planned to enforce a new law making it a crime to cheat, punishable by up to seven years in jail.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Narendra Modi Bolsters India’s Ties With U.S., Thanks (Partly) to Donald Trump
item.description: Pacts on Tuesday included a crucial step to ratify the Paris climate accord and finishing the purchase of nuclear reactors, with a military deal to come.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS and CORAL DAVENPORT

item.title: Militant Islamists Are Suspected in Slaying of Hindu Priest in Bangladesh
item.media:description: The Hindu priest Anando Gopal Ganguly and his wife, Shefali Ganguly, in an undated photograph taken at their house in Jhenidah, Bangladesh.
item.description: The priest, Anando Gopal Ganguly, was riding a bicycle when three men on a motorcycle attacked him from behind, the police said.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Money, Jobs and Sovereignty: Myth vs. Reality Ahead of ‘Brexit’ Vote
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the former mayor of London, during the Brexit Battle Bus tour in York, England, in May.
item.description: As Britain prepares to vote on June 23 on European Union membership, both sides of the debate warn of dangerous outcomes. We debunk, or back up, their claims.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: What in the World: An All-Purpose Maze Deep Beneath a London Suburb
item.media:credit: Illustration by Leif Parsons; Photos by Jag_cz, Andrey Yurlov, Ollie, Graeme Dawes/shutterstock
item.description: The Chislehurst Caves have been an arsenal, a bomb shelter, a concert site, a film set, and once even a makeshift maternity ward. But they’ve never been caves.
item.dc:creator: DES SHOE

item.title: What in the World: In Croatia, You’ll Finally No Longer Need the Stamp of Approval
item.description: The centuries-old ritual of the rubber stamp and its “clah-thunk” for documents is giving way to digital in a country bogged down by bureaucracy.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH OROVIC

item.title: What in the World: Hong Kong’s Murder Mystery: Who Is Poisoning the Dogs?
item.media:description: An older sign on Bowen Road, a popular dog-walking path, cautioned owners to be vigilant.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: Over 200 dogs may have been poisoned since the 1980s, but officials do not know who is responsible or what the motives may be.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals

item.title: Saudis Hand Over Child Soldiers Captured in Yemen, Official Says
item.description: The Yemeni foreign minister, Abdel-Malek al-Mekhlafi, said the 54 child prisoners had been captured in fighting with the rebel Houthi militia.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Kerrey’s Vietnam Dilemma
item.description: Former Senator Bob Kerrey should not quit his role at the new Fulbright University Vietnam, despite an outcry over his war record.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Aging, but Still Working, in Singapore
item.media:description: Dealing with an aging population is one of the major challenges that Singapore faces as it cements its status as an advanced nation.
item.description: The city-state already has the world’s longest working hours. Soon, it’ll have the longest working lives, too.
item.dc:creator: TASH AW

item.title: Editorial: Will the Vatican Discipline Offending Bishops?
item.media:description: Pope Francis in Saint Peter’s Square at the Vatican last week.
item.description: The church faithful will be watching to see whether diocesan leaders will ever be made answerable.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Have You Voted for a Far-Right Party in Europe? Share Your Thoughts
item.media:description: Supporters of the far-right Freedom Party at a rally in Vienna last month.
item.description: The Times is collecting the personal experiences of voters who have backed those groups. Whom did you support? What motivated you?
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
